[TITLE]
<line: 25> UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
<line: 26> WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON
<line: 27> AT SEATTLE

[TEXT]
<line: 29> EKO BRANDS, LLC,

[TEXT]
<line: 31> Plaintiff,

[TEXT]
<line: 33> C17-894 TSZ

[TEXT]
<line: 35> v.

[TITLE]
<line: 37> FINDINGS OF FACT AND
<line: 38> CONCLUSIONS OF LAW

[TEXT]
<line: 40> ADRIAN RIVERA MAYNEZ
<line: 41> ENTERPRISES, INC.; and ADRIAN
<line: 42> RIVERA,

[TEXT]
<line: 44> Defendants.

[TEXT]
<line: 46> THIS MATTER came on for trial on September 16, 2019, before the Court, sitting
<line: 47> with an advisory jury.' Plaintiff Eko Brands, LLC was represented by David Lowe and
<line: 48> Lawrence Graham of Lowe Graham Jones PLLC. Defendants Adrian Rivera Maynez
<line: 49> Enterprises, Inc. and Adrian Rivera were represented by Kenneth R. Davis II of Lane
<line: 50> Powell PC. Trial proceeded for four days and ended on September 19, 2019, at which

[TEXT]
<line: 52> 1 By Minute Order entered September 16, 2019, docket no. 119, the Court directed plaintiff to
<line: 53> show cause why it should not be sanctioned for failing to make mandatory disclosures in.
<line: 54> discovery concerning the actual damages it sought in this action. In response, after the first day
<line: 55> of trial, plaintiff withdrew its claim for actual damages, see Pla.'s Resp. at 4 (docket no. 120),
<line: 56> leaving only plaintiff's claims for equitable relief. Because a jury had already been impaneled,
<line: 57> the Court decided to proceed under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 39(c), and treat any verdict.
<line: 58> as advisory. The Court is "at liberty to accept or reject the advisory verdict." Chicago & N.W.
<line: 59> Ry. Co. v. Minn. Transfer Ry. Co., 371 F.2d 129, 130 (8th Cir. 1967); see Reachi v. Edmond, 277
<line: 60> F.2d 850, 854 (9th Cir. 1960) (an advisory jury's verdict is *not binding upon the trial court').

[TEXT]
<line: 62> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 1

[ABANDON]

<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> time the advisory jury began deliberations.  At the end of the day on September 20, 2019, 
<line: 27> the advisory jury rendered a partial verdict, docket no. 136. 
<line: 28> Having considered the advisory jury’s partial verdict, the testimony of the 
<line: 29> witnesses,2 the exhibits admitted into evidence,3 the facts on which the parties have 
<line: 30> agreed,4 and the oral and written arguments of counsel, including defendants’ motion for 
<line: 31> judgment, docket no. 125, plaintiff’s response, docket no. 146, defendants’ reply in 
<line: 32> support of their motion for judgment, docket no. 147, plaintiff’s proposed findings of fact 
<line: 33> and conclusions of law, docket no. 144, defendants’ objections, docket no. 145, and 
<line: 34> plaintiff’s response to such objections, docket no. 148, the Court now ENTERS these 
<line: 35> Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 
<line: 36> 52(a).  Any conclusion of law misidentified as a finding of fact shall be deemed a 
<line: 37> conclusion of law, and any finding of fact misidentified as a conclusion of law shall be 
<line: 38> deemed a finding of fact. 

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 4 See Pretrial Order at § D (docket nos. 105 & 106); Court’s Instruction No. 5 (docket no. 129). 

[ABANDON]
<line: 42> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 2 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> of Civil Procedure 52(c). Defendants' Rule 52(c) motion is GRANTED in part and
<line: 3> DENIED in part as indicated, and for the reasons set forth, in the following Findings of
<line: 4> 3  Fact and Conclusions of Law.

[ABANDON]

[TITLE]
<line: 27> Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law

[TITLE]
<line: 29> A.
<line: 30> Parties and Jurisdiction

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 1.
<line: 33> Plaintiff Eko Brands, LLC (Eko Brands') is a Washington limited liability.
<line: 34> company having a principal place of business in Woodinville, Washington.

[TEXT]
<line: 36> 2.
<line: 37> Eko Brands is in the business of manufacturing and selling reusable
<line: 38> beverage cartridges that are commonly used with single-serve coffee makers, such as
<line: 39> those sold under the Keurig@ brand. Eko also sells paper filters and cleaning tablets to be
<line: 40> used in connection with the reusable beverage cartridges..

[TEXT]
<line: 42> 3.
<line: 43> Eko Brands has received Certificates of Registration from the United States
<line: 44> Patent and Trademark Office ("PTO") for the trademarks EKOBREW and the ekOOrew
<line: 45> design (collectively, the "EKOBREw Marks"). The Certificates of Registration, bearing
<line: 46> Registration Nos. 5,073,356 and 5,073,357, respectively, were issued on November 1,
<line: 47> 2016, and they indicate that the EKOBREw Marks were first used on September 7, 2011,
<line: 48> in connection with reusable filters, not made of paper, for use in electric brewing
<line: 49> machines for beverages.

[TEXT]
<line: 51> 4.
<line: 52> Defendant Adrian Rivera Maynez Enterprises, Inc. ("ARM') is a Nevada.
<line: 53> corporation having a principal place of business in California..

[ABANDON]
<line: 55> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 3

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 3
<line: 3> 6
<line: 4> 11
<line: 5> 12
<line: 6> 13
<line: 7> 14
<line: 8> 15
<line: 9> 16paper coffee filters.
<line: 10> 17
<line: 11> 18
<line: 12> ECO-FLOW in January 2016. ARM began selling cleaning kits for reusable beverage.
<line: 13> 19
<line: 14> 20applied to the PTO for registration of the marks ECOSAVE and the ecosavedesign,
<line: 15> 21
<line: 16> 22
<line: 17> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 19> 5.
<line: 20> Defendant Adrian Rivera is the owner, founder, and president of ARM, and.
<line: 21> resides in California.

[TEXT]
<line: 23> 6.
<line: 24> Defendants are in the business of manufacturing and selling reusable
<line: 25>  beverage cartridges that are commonly used with single-serve coffee makers, such as
<line: 26> those sold under the Keurig brand.

[TEXT]
<line: 28> 7.
<line: 29> Rivera has received Certificates of Registration from the PTO for the
<line: 30> trademarks ECO FILL, ECO CARAFE, ECO FILTER, PERFECT POD, and EZ-CUP
<line: 31> Certificate of Registration No. 4.239.190 for ECO FILL was issued on November 6
<line: 32> 2012, and indicates that ECO FILL was first used on September 7, 2012, in connection.
<line: 33> with reusable single serving coffee filters, not made of paper, which are part of an electric.
<line: 34> coffee maker. Certificate of Registration No. 4,796,840 for ECO CARAFE was issued
<line: 35> on August 18, 2015, and indicates that ECO CARAFE was first used on February 4,
<line: 36> 2015, in connection with empty brewing cartridges for use in electric coffee machines.
<line: 37> Certificate of Registration No. 5,741,858 for ECO FILTER was issued on April 30, 2019,
<line: 38> and indicates that ECO FILTER was first used on August 31, 2017, in connection with

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 8.
<line: 41> ARM began selling reusable beverage filter capsules under the mark
<line: 42> filter capsules under the mark ECO-PURE in 2018. On May 16, 2019, Mr. Rivera
<line: 43> indicating that he and/or ARM intend to use the marks in connection with reusable filter
<line: 44> cartridges for use in electric coffee brewing machines..

[ABANDON]
<line: 46> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 4

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> 9. 
<line: 27> ARM’s sales of products under the marks ECO FILL, ECO CARAFE, and 
<line: 28> ECO-FLOW between January 1, 2012, and July 31, 2019, totaled $17,952,815.00.  
<line: 29> ARM’s sales of products under the marks ECO FILTER, ECO-PURE, and ECOSAVE 
<line: 30> through July 31, 2019, totaled $170,995.00. 
<line: 31> 10. 
<line: 32> Eko Brands brought suit against ARM under Sections 32 and 43 of the 
<line: 33> Lanham Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1114 & 1125, alleging trademark infringement and unfair 
<line: 34> competition in connection with ARM’s use of the marks ECO FILL, ECO CARAFE, 
<line: 35> ECO-FLOW, ECO FILTER, ECO-PURE, and ECOSAVE.  The Court concludes that 
<line: 36> federal jurisdiction exists pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1338. 

[TITLE]
<line: 38> B. 
<line: 39> Eko Brands’ Claims and Burdens of Proof 

[TEXT]
<line: 41> 11. 
<line: 42> In connection with the first claim of trademark infringement, Eko Brands 
<line: 43> must prove each of the following elements by a preponderance of the evidence:  
<line: 44> (i) EKOBREW is a valid, protectable trademark; (ii) Eko Brands owns EKOBREW as a 
<line: 45> trademark; and (iii) on or after November 1, 2016, defendants used a mark similar to 
<line: 46> EKOBREW without Eko Brands’ consent in a manner that was likely to cause confusion 
<line: 47> among ordinary consumers as to the source, sponsorship, affiliation, or approval of the 
<line: 48> goods.  See 9th Cir. Model Instr. No. 15.6; Court’s Instruction No. 14 (docket no. 129). 
<line: 49> 12. 
<line: 50> In connection with the second claim of unfair competition, Eko Brands 
<line: 51> must prove each of the following elements by a preponderance of the evidence:  
<line: 52> (i) EKOBREW was a valid, protectable trademark prior to when defendants first used 
<line: 53> ECO FILL; (ii) Eko Brands owns EKOBREW as a trademark; and (iii) during the period 
<line: 54> prior to November 1, 2016, defendants used a mark similar to EKOBREW without 

[ABANDON]
<line: 56> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 5 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> Eko Brands’ consent in a manner that was likely to cause confusion among ordinary 
<line: 27> consumers as to the source, sponsorship, affiliation, or approval of the goods.  See 
<line: 28> Court’s Instruction No. 15 (docket no. 129). 

[TITLE]
<line: 30> Validity and Ownership of EKOBREW Marks 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 13. 
<line: 33> To be valid and protectable, a trademark must be either:  (i) inherently 
<line: 34> distinctive; or (ii) descriptive with an acquired secondary meaning.  See 9th Cir. Model 
<line: 35> Instr. Nos. 15.10 & 15.11; Court’s Instruction No. 14B. 

[TEXT]
<line: 37> 14. 
<line: 38> Eko Brands contends that EKOBREW is a “suggestive” trademark and 
<line: 39> therefore inherently distinctive.  Defendants assert that EKOBREW is merely a 
<line: 40> “descriptive” trademark that has not acquired any secondary meaning and, as a result, is 
<line: 41> not valid or protectable.  The advisory jury was asked whether the EKOBREW mark is 
<line: 42> “suggestive” or “descriptive,” but it could not reach a unanimous verdict.  See Verdict 
<line: 43> (docket no. 136).  The advisory jury, however, found that the EKOBREW mark had 
<line: 44> acquired secondary meaning before defendants first began to use ECO FILL.  Id. 

[TEXT]
<line: 46> 15. 
<line: 47> In determining whether a trademark has acquired a secondary meaning, the 
<line: 48> following factors may be considered: 

[TEXT]
<line: 50> (1) 
<line: 51> Consumer Perception.  Whether people who purchase the 
<line: 52> product that bears the trademark associate the trademark with plaintiff; 

[TEXT]
<line: 54> (2) 
<line: 55> Advertisement.  To what degree and in what manner has 
<line: 56> plaintiff advertised under the trademark; 

[TEXT]
<line: 58> (3) 
<line: 59> Demonstrated Utility.  Whether plaintiff successfully used the 
<line: 60> trademark to increase the sales of its product; 

[TEXT]
<line: 62> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 6 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> (4) 
<line: 27> Extent of Use.  The length of time and manner in which 
<line: 28> plaintiff used the trademark; 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> (5) 
<line: 31> Exclusivity.  Whether plaintiff’s use of the trademark was 
<line: 32> exclusive; 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> (6) 
<line: 35> Copying.  Whether defendants intentionally copied plaintiff’s 
<line: 36> trademark; and 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> (7) 
<line: 39> Actual Confusion.  Whether defendants’ use of plaintiff’s 
<line: 40> trademark has led to actual confusion among a significant number of 
<line: 41> consumers. 

[TEXT]
<line: 43> The presence or absence of any particular factor does not necessarily resolve whether a 
<line: 44> trademark has acquired secondary meaning.  A trademark does not need to be used for 
<line: 45> any particular length of time to acquire a secondary meaning.  See 9th Cir. Model Instr. 
<line: 46> No. 15.11; Court’s Instruction No. 14B. 

[TEXT]
<line: 48> 16. 
<line: 49> Regardless of whether the EKOBREW Marks are “suggestive” or 
<line: 50> “descriptive,” they are valid and protectable because they acquired secondary meaning 
<line: 51> before defendants began using ECO FILL in September 2012. 

[TEXT]
<line: 53> 17. 
<line: 54> As early as June 2011, Eko Brands received purchase orders from Amazon 
<line: 55> and J.C. Wright Sales Company (on behalf of QFC) for its EKOBREW reusable coffee 
<line: 56> (or beverage) filters for Keurig® single cup brewers; product deliveries were scheduled 
<line: 57> for mid July 2011.  During the same timeframe, Eko Brands was marketing and selling its 
<line: 58> EKOBREW filters on the Internet through its website www.ekobrew.com. 

[TEXT]
<line: 60> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 7 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23
<line: 25> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 8 
<line: 26> 18. 
<line: 27> When EKOBREW reusable filters debuted in September 2011, they were 
<line: 28> the #1 new release in the Amazon.com grocery category.  In the spring of 2012, the 
<line: 29> EKOBREW cartridge was among the five finalists for a Housewares Design Award.  By 
<line: 30> the end of 2012, Eko Brands had sold 262,994 cases of EKOBREW filters (12 per case), 
<line: 31> generating just over $9.5 million in gross revenue.  See Ex. 123 at EKOTM0254453; see 
<line: 32> also Tr. (Sep. 18, 2019) at 355:10-356:12 (docket no. 140). 
<line: 33> 19. 
<line: 34> As of April 2013, Eko Brands used for its EKOBREW cartridges both 
<line: 35> cylindrical and rectangular packaging, with clear portions through which the product can 
<line: 36> be viewed.  In late 2013 and early 2014, Eko Brands began extending its use of the 
<line: 37> EKOBREW Marks to other items, namely paper filters and cleaning tablets.  As of 
<line: 38> April 2014, the top distributors or retailers of the EKOBREW “flagship” product were 
<line: 39> Ahold, Amazon, Bed Bath & Beyond, KeHe Distributors, Safeway, and Walmart.  By 
<line: 40> the time Eko Brands was acquired in 2015 by Espresso Supply, Inc., approximately 
<line: 41> 10 million EKOBREW filters had been sold.  In March 2016, Eko Brands introduced an 
<line: 42> EKOBREW “carafe” reusable filter for multi-cup brewing in the Keurig® 2.0 machine. 
<line: 43> 20. 
<line: 44> Eko Brands has several competitors in the reusable cartridge market, 
<line: 45> including Keurig’s MY K-CUP, Solofill, Melitta’s JAVA JIG, and CAFÉ CUP.  ARM is 
<line: 46> the only company other than Eko Brands to use the EKO or ECO prefix in a trademark 
<line: 47> associated with filters for Keurig® and similar brewing machines. 
<line: 48> 21. 
<line: 49> As of September 2012, when defendants began using ECO FILL, the 
<line: 50> EKOBREW Marks were linked with the industry leader at the time, i.e., Eko Brands.  
<line: 51> By then, the EKOBREW reusable filters had already gained recognition from the largest 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> e-commerce company in the United States (Amazon) and the trade publication 
<line: 27> (HomeWorld Business) that sponsors the annual Housewares Design Awards.  Eko 
<line: 28> Brands had devoted substantial resources to advertising under the EKOBREW Marks, 
<line: 29> developing a website with the same name (www.ekobrew.com), attending trade shows, 
<line: 30> and participating in social media.  Before defendants started branding with ECO FILL, 
<line: 31> the EKOBREW Marks had demonstrated their utility, being linked to a product that 
<line: 32> almost doubled in sales from 2011 to 2012.  During this same timeframe, no competitor 
<line: 33> used a similar mark.  The Court therefore ADOPTS the advisory jury’s verdict that the 
<line: 34> EKOBREW Marks acquired secondary meaning before defendants first began to use 
<line: 35> ECO FILL. 

[TEXT]
<line: 37> 22. 
<line: 38> Although a close call, as indicated by the advisory jury’s inability to reach a 
<line: 39> verdict, the EKOBREW Marks are suggestive and therefore inherently distinctive.  
<line: 40> Whether a trademark is “suggestive” or “descriptive” must be determined with reference 
<line: 41> to the goods that the trademark identifies.  A trademark, however, need not recite in detail 
<line: 42> each feature of the related goods to qualify as merely descriptive.  To be descriptive, a 
<line: 43> trademark only has to describe some aspect of the product.  Two tests apply when 
<line: 44> determining whether a trademark is “suggestive” or “descriptive,” namely (i) the 
<line: 45> “imagination” test; and (ii) the “needs” test.  The “imagination” test asks whether a 
<line: 46> mental leap is required to reach a conclusion concerning the nature of the product being 
<line: 47> referenced by the trademark.  The question is not what information could be derived from 
<line: 48> the trademark, but rather whether a mental leap is required to understand the trademark’s 
<line: 49> relationship to the product.  If a mental leap is required, then the trademark is suggestive.  

[ABANDON]
<line: 51> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 9 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> If a mental leap is not required, then the trademark is descriptive.  The “needs” test 
<line: 3> focuses on the extent to which a trademark (or one of its components) is needed by 
<line: 4> competitors to identify their goods.  If competitors have a great need to use the 
<line: 5> trademark, then the trademark is more likely to be descriptive.  On the other hand, if the 
<line: 6> relationship between the trademark and the product is so remote and subtle that the 
<line: 7> trademark is not really needed by competitors to describe their goods, then the trademark 
<line: 8> is more likely to be suggestive.  See 9th Cir. Model Instr. Nos. 15.10 & 15.11; Court’s 
<line: 9> Instruction No. 14B; see also Zobmondo Entm’t, LLC v. Falls Media, LLC, 602 F.3d 
<line: 10> 1108, 1117 (9th Cir. 2010). 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> 23. 
<line: 13> The EKOBREW Marks were determined to be inherently distinctive by the 
<line: 14> PTO; such finding was a prerequisite to the issuance of Certificates of Registration for 
<line: 15> the EKOBREW Marks.5 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> 24. 
<line: 18> When asked about ARM’s competing ECO FILL trademark, Rivera 
<line: 19> testified that he believed the mark was distinctive and entitled to protection, and he 
<line: 20> agreed that, likewise, EKOBREW “should be protected on its own.”  Tr. (Sep. 17, 2019) 
<line: 21> at 223:22 (docket no. 139).  Rivera’s view is that EKOBREW and ECO FILL are both 
<line: 22> protectable trademarks, but they are not similar and can co-exist.  See id. at 223:22–
<line: 23> 224:3. 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> 5 Although Eko Brands was originally unsuccessful in securing registration of the EKOBREW 
<line: 26> Marks, the reason cited by the PTO was not lack of distinctiveness, but rather similarity to an 
<line: 27> already registered mark, namely ECO BREW, which is owned by Thomas Hammer Coffee 
<line: 28> Roasting, Inc. of Spokane, Washington, and used in connection with coffee beans.  Eko Brands 
<line: 29> and Thomas Hammer Coffee Roasting, Inc. subsequently entered into a trademark coexistence 
<line: 30> agreement. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 32> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 10 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> 25. 
<line: 27> Both the PTO’s decision to permit registration of the EKOBREW Marks 
<line: 28> and Rivera’s concession on the subject support a finding that the EKOBREW Marks are 
<line: 29> valid.  Moreover, both the “imagination” test and the “needs” test lead to the conclusion 
<line: 30> that the EKOBREW Marks are “suggestive,” rather than merely “descriptive.”  Although 
<line: 31> the term ECO, or its phonetic equivalent EKO,6 in combination with BREW, connotes an 
<line: 32> ecological or environmentally-friendly brewing solution, it does not itself describe the 
<line: 33> approach embodied in the EKOBREW products.  Rather, a “mental leap” is required to 
<line: 34> understand that the device referenced by the EKOBREW Marks is a reusable filter or 
<line: 35> cartridge for a single-serving beverage brewing machine.  This conclusion is reinforced 
<line: 36> by the absence of competitors other than ARM that use ECO or EKO, or BREW, as part 
<line: 37> of their brand names.  The lack of “need” demonstrated by this evidence tends to show 
<line: 38> that EKOBREW is “suggestive,” rather than “descriptive.”  The Court’s finding that 
<line: 39> EKOBREW is “suggestive” and therefore inherently distinctive constitutes an alternative 
<line: 40> basis for concluding that the EKOBREW Marks are valid and protectable. 

[TEXT]
<line: 42> 6 Eko Brands contends that EKO is a fanciful or coined word entitled to be treated as “arbitrary” 
<line: 43> for the purpose of determining its inherent distinctiveness.  Such argument runs contrary to the 
<line: 44> weight of authorities.  See Armstrong Paint & Varnish Works v. Nu-Enamel Corp., 305 U.S. 315, 
<line: 45> 328 (1938) (observing that “the mark ‘Nu-Enamel’ is descriptive of a type of paint long familiar 
<line: 46> to manufacturers, with the addition of the adjective new, phonetically spelled or misspelled”); 
<line: 47> Unisplay S.A. v. Am. Elec. Sign Co., 28 U.S.P.Q.2d 1721 (E.D. Wash. 1993) (concluding that 
<line: 48> “Solar Glo,” which incorporated an incomplete form of “glow,” was descriptive and had no 
<line: 49> secondary meaning); In re Calphalon Corp., 122 U.S.P.Q.2d 1153 (T.T.A.B. 2017) (affirming 
<line: 50> the refusal to register SHARPIN, as being equivalent to “sharpen,” which was merely descriptive 
<line: 51> in connection with cutlery blocks containing built-in blade sharpeners). 

[TEXT]
<line: 53> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 11 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> 26. 
<line: 27> Regardless of whether the EKOBREW Marks are “suggestive” or 
<line: 28> “descriptive,” Eko Brands owned the EKOBREW Marks before defendants first began to 
<line: 29> use ECO FILL.  If the EKOBREW Marks are “suggestive,” then Eko Brands has the 
<line: 30> burden of showing by a preponderance of the evidence that it used the EKOBREW 
<line: 31> Marks for its products before defendants began to use ECO FILL to market their products 
<line: 32> in the area where Eko Brands sells its product.  On the other hand, if the EKOBREW 
<line: 33> Marks are “descriptive,” then Eko Brands has the burden of showing by a preponderance 
<line: 34> of the evidence that the EKOBREW Marks gained secondary meaning before defendants 
<line: 35> first began to use ECO FILL.  See 9th Cir. Model Instr. No. 15.13; Court’s Instruction 
<line: 36> No. 14C.  For the same reasons outlined with respect to the validity of the EKOBREW 
<line: 37> Marks, the Court ADOPTS the advisory jury’s verdict that Eko Brands has made the 
<line: 38> requisite showing of ownership of the EKOBREW Marks. 

[TITLE]
<line: 40> D. 
<line: 41> Likelihood of Confusion 

[TEXT]
<line: 43> 27. 
<line: 44> Defendants’ use of their “ECO” trademarks is likely to cause confusion 
<line: 45> about the source of Eko Brands’ and/or ARM’s goods.  In connection with its first claim 
<line: 46> of trademark infringement occurring on or after November 1, 2016, Eko Brands 
<line: 47> challenges the following ARM trademarks:  ECO FILL, ECO CARAFE, ECO-FLOW, 
<line: 48> ECO FILTER, ECOSAVE, and ECO-PURE.  With respect to its second claim of unfair 
<line: 49> competition occurring before November 1, 2016, Eko Brands contends that the following 
<line: 50> ARM trademarks were infringing:  ECO FILL, ECO CARAFE, and ECO-FLOW. 
<line: 51> 28. 
<line: 52> ARM first generated revenue in November 2012 from use of the ECO FILL 
<line: 53> mark.  ARM began deriving income in connection with the ECO CARAFE mark in 2015, 

[ABANDON]
<line: 55> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 12 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> the ECO-FLOW mark in 2017, and the ECO FILTER, ECOSAVE, and ECO-PURE 
<line: 27> marks in 2019.  See Exs. 274 & 473. 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 29. 
<line: 30> Like Eko Brands, ARM maintains a website (www.perfectpod.com) 
<line: 31> through which it markets and sells its products.  ARM also has a presence on Amazon 
<line: 32> and on social media, and has participated in the same trade shows (within the same 
<line: 33> exhibition space) as Eko Brands.  ARM distributes its products through “big-box” 
<line: 34> retailers like Target and Bed Bath & Beyond, as well as through “regional chains” like 
<line: 35> Meijer, but not within grocery stores, like Safeway, which is among Eko Brands’ top 
<line: 36> customers for EKOBREW products.  Tr. (Sep. 18, 2019) at 423:22-424:5 (docket 
<line: 37> no. 140); Exs. 149 & 167.  ARM had a relationship with Walmart until late 2012 or early 
<line: 38> 2013, when Eko Brands secured a contract with the retailer and ARM lost the account.  
<line: 39> Id. at 425:10-20.  Eko Brands’ EKOBREW filters and ARM’s ECO FILL capsules are 
<line: 40> priced within the same range ($5 to $12), and they are considered “impulse” buys as to 
<line: 41> which purchasers perform little to no advance research. 

[TEXT]
<line: 43> 30. 
<line: 44> In comparing the accused trademarks with the EKOBREW Marks to 
<line: 45> determine whether a likelihood of confusion exists, the Court has considered, as it must, 
<line: 46> each mark as a whole, and not merely a component of the marks, and the Court has 
<line: 47> applied the non-exhaustive Sleekcraft factors, which are as follows:  (1) strength or 
<line: 48> weakness of the marks; (2) proximity of the goods; (3) similarity of the marks; (4) actual 
<line: 49> confusion; (5) marketing channels used; (6) consumer’s degree of care; (7) defendants’ 
<line: 50> intent; and (8) likelihood of product line expansion.  The Court has been mindful that the 
<line: 51> presence or absence of any particular factor does not necessarily resolve the question of 

[ABANDON]
<line: 53> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 13 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> whether confusion is likely. See 9th Cir. Model Instr. No. 15.18; Court's Instruction
<line: 3> No. 14D; see also AMF Inc. v. Sleekcraft Boats, 599 F.2d 341, 348-49 (9th Cir. 1979).
<line: 4> 31.
<line: 5>  Although the marks at issue are fairly weak,' a finding of infringement is
<line: 6> nevertheless supported by the proximity of the goods with which they are associated (i.e.,
<line: 7> 5  direct competitors), the similarity of the marks (containing an aurally-identical prefix),
<line: 8>  and the overlap in marketing channels within which the products are advertised and travel
<line: 9> (namely, e-commerce and certain brick-and-mortar retailers). See Sleekcraft, 599 F.2d at
<line: 10>  350 (observing that "[a]lthough appellant's mark is protectible and may have been.
<line: 11> 9  strengthened by advertising, it is a weak mark entitled to a restricted range of protection"
<line: 12> 10  and "only if the marks are quite similar, and the goods closely related, will infringement
<line: 13> be found' (citations omitted)). In addition, the inexpensive nature of the products and the
<line: 14>  resultant lack of caution exercised by consumers, as well as both Eko Brands' and
<line: 15> 13
<line: 16> ARM's efforts to expand the use of their respective marks to complementary products,
<line: 17> 14
<line: 18> like paper filters and cleaning materials, weigh in favor of finding some likelihood of
<line: 19> confusion.8 Finally, defendants' intent to exploit Eko Brands' success by adopting a

[ABANDON]
<line: 21> 3
<line: 22> 6.
<line: 23> 11
<line: 24> 12
<line: 25> 15
<line: 26> 16
<line: 27> 17
<line: 28> 18
<line: 29> 19
<line: 30> 20
<line: 31> 21
<line: 32> 22
<line: 33> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 35> 7 A strong mark is one that is arbitrary or fanciful, while a descriptive mark is much weaker and
<line: 36> will not enjoy protection absent proof of secondary meaning; a suggestive mark falls somewhere
<line: 37> in the middle. See Sleekcraft, 599 F.2d at 349. On the continuum of types of trademarks, both
<line: 38> EKOBREW and ECO FILL are close to the boundary of descriptiveness, and neither mark is
<line: 39> entitled to the "wide ambit' of protection afforded to arbitrary or fanciful marks. See id.

[TEXT]
<line: 41> 8 At trial, Eko Brands presented no evidence of any surveys or litigation studies done to assess
<line: 42> whether confusion is likely or actually exists. Eko Brands offered only anecdotal evidence of a
<line: 43> few instances of confusion, one involving an individual, Rabbi Zev Schwartz, who bought a
<line: 44> machine manufactured by one of Keurig's competitors (OXX) and inquired of an Eko Brands'
<line: 45> customer service agent whether ARM's ECO FILL cartridge would work in his device, another
<line: 46> in which representatives from Bonavita (which makes automatic coffee brewers) and a Chinese

[ABANDON]
<line: 48> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 14

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 2
<line: 3>   section, further persuades the Court that the advisory jury reached the correct result, and
<line: 4> 3 its verdict that a likelihood of confusion exists between the EKOBREW Marks and each
<line: 5> E.
<line: 6> 6
<line: 7> 7
<line: 8> Court's Instruction No. 18; see 15 U.S.C.  1117(a); see also Stone Creek, Inc. v. Omnia
<line: 9> 11
<line: 10> 12
<line: 11> 13
<line: 12> 14
<line: 13> 15
<line: 14> 16
<line: 15> 17
<line: 16> 18
<line: 17> 19
<line: 18> 20
<line: 19> 21
<line: 20> 22 in the Sleekcraft factors.
<line: 21> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 23> visually and aurally similar mark, as will be discussed in further detail in the subsequent
<line: 24> of ARM's marks, namely ECO FILL, ECO CARAFE, ECO-FLOW, ECO FILTER,
<line: 25> ECOSAVE, and ECO-PURE, is ADOPTED.

[TITLE]
<line: 27> Willfulness

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 32.
<line: 30>  To be entitled to the disgorgement of defendants' profits, Eko Brands must
<line: 31> prove by a preponderance of the evidence that defendants' infringement was willful
<line: 32> Italian Design, Inc., 875 F.3d 426, 439-42 (9th Cir. 2017). Conduct is "willful' if it is
<line: 33> calculated to exploit the advantage of an established trademark or it is done deliberately
<line: 34> with an intent to deceive. Court's Instruction No. 16; see Lindy Pen Co. v. Bic Pen
<line: 35> Corp., 982 F.2d 1400, 1405-06 (9th Cir. 1993), abrogated in part on other grounds by
<line: 36> SunEarth, Inc. v. Sun Earth Solar Power Co., 839 F.3d 1179 (9th Cir. 2016).

[TEXT]
<line: 38> 33.
<line: 39>  Before adopting the ECO FILL mark in 2012, defendants used the marks
<line: 40> PERFECT POD and EZ-CUP. The PERFECT POD EZ-CUP consists of a small plastic
<line: 41> cup or cartridge that would hold a paper filter into which coffee grounds could be placed

[TEXT]
<line: 43>  glass factory mistook ARM's ECO FILL capsule as an EKOBREW product and brought it to a
<line: 44> meeting with Laura Sommers, one of the owners of Eko Brands, and unspecified times when
<line: 45> unidentified friends of Christopher Legler, another owner of Eko Brands, told him they had
<line: 46> purchased an EKOBREW filter from a retailer that does not sell the product. Given the volume
<line: 47> of sales at issue, these isolated events do not establish the type of "actual confusion"' referenced

[ABANDON]
<line: 49> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 15

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 3
<line: 3> 5
<line: 4> 6
<line: 5> 8
<line: 6> 9
<line: 7> 10
<line: 8> 11
<line: 9> 12
<line: 10> 13
<line: 11> 14
<line: 12> 15
<line: 13> 16
<line: 14> 17
<line: 15> 18
<line: 16> 19
<line: 17> 20
<line: 18> 21
<line: 19> 22
<line: 20> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 22> for brewing. In 2011, defendants began developing a plastic capsule with an integrated
<line: 23>  metal filter or screen. In connection with this new product, defendants considered the
<line: 24> names GREEN CUP and EZ-FILL, which was a natural extension of the existing mark
<line: 25> EZ-CUP. In November 2011, a designer was commissioned to provide branding and
<line: 26> packaging concepts for EZ-FILL. On December 3, 2011, the designer proposed three
<line: 27>  different EZ-FILL logos, each to be incorporated on rectangular packages with clear
<line: 28> portions through which the product could be viewed. The options were as follows:

<line: 24> of ECO, the letters of which are green, contrasted with FILL in yellow letters, against a
<line: 25>  brown background with an orange border. During this same timeframe, Eko Brands used
<line: 26> cup with lines emanating upward (suggestive of steam, but forming the shape of a plant),
<line: 27> all against a dark brown background

[TEXT]
<line: 42> 36.
<line: 43> On December 19, 2011, Rivera applied to the PTO to register ECO FILL,
<line: 44> indicating anticipated first use of the mark in September 2012. In contrast, Rivera did not
<line: 45> seek registration of PERFECT POD until February 2016, even though the mark is part of
<line: 46> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 17

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5

<line: 9> 8

<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> defendants’ website address and had been used in connection with the EZ-CUP product 
<line: 27> since at least 2010 and with respect to paper filters since 2006. 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 37. 
<line: 30> Dino Ditta, the Vice President of ARM, testified that the name ECO FILL 
<line: 31> was associated with the new reusable filter from “day one” of its development, which 
<line: 32> was sometime in April 2011.  Tr. (Sep. 18, 2019) at 418:20-419:1 (docket no. 140).  This 
<line: 33> statement is inconsistent with the decision to pay a designer $5,800 to work exclusively 
<line: 34> on a logo and packaging for an entirely different mark, i.e., EZ-FILL.  See Ex. 98.  The 
<line: 35> Court finds that defendants did not contemplate using the mark ECO FILL until early 
<line: 36> December 2011, after receiving the designer’s initial concepts for EZ-FILL. 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> 38. 
<line: 39> Rivera testified that he did not know about Eko Brands or EKOBREW in 
<line: 40> 2011, before he sought to federally register the ECO FILL mark.  Tr. (Sep. 17, 2019) at 
<line: 41> 184:11-185:15 (docket no. 139).  Having observed Rivera’s demeanor during trial and 
<line: 42> considered the other evidence in the record, the Court finds that Rivera’s denial of 
<line: 43> knowledge is not credible.  The evidence establishes that, before EKOBREW’s launch in 
<line: 44> September 2011, defendants intended to simply extend their “EZ” line by calling their 
<line: 45> new product EZ-FILL.  In December 2011, after committing resources to develop a logo 
<line: 46> and packaging for the EZ-FILL mark, defendants abruptly changed course and adopted 
<line: 47> the ECO FILL mark.  Given the absence of any explanation for this behavior,9 the Court 

[TEXT]
<line: 49> 9 Ditta testified that the designer defendants had employed, Al Nanakonpanom (“Nana”), died in 
<line: 50> 2015.  Although Nana was not available as a witness, any direction he had been given to perform 
<line: 51> extra work at “no additional cost” on “some ‘spectacular’ logo concepts,” Ex. 168, could have 
<line: 52> been discussed at trial by Rivera and/or Ditta, and the Court concludes that defendants were not 
<line: 53> prejudiced by Nana’s absence. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 55> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 18 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> finds that it was calculated to exploit the success EKOBREW had experienced in the 
<line: 3> preceding months. 
<line: 4> 39. 
<line: 5> In response to questioning by Eko Brands’ counsel, Rivera acknowledged 
<line: 6> at trial that he keeps his eyes on the competition by monitoring Amazon and other 
<line: 7> marketplaces, but he speculated that he did not become aware of EKOBREW until late 
<line: 8> 2012 or “maybe 2013.”  Tr. (Sep. 17, 2019) at 181:5-184:4, 184:20-21 (docket no. 139).  
<line: 9> EKOBREW’s status as a #1 new release on Amazon in September 2011 could not have 
<line: 10> escaped Rivera’s and/or Ditta’s notice for long, and certainly not for a year or more, as 
<line: 11> Rivera suggests.  Moreover, Rivera’s estimate of learning about EKOBREW in late 2012 
<line: 12> or 2013 is contradicted by Ditta’s testimony that, in January 2012, a manufacturer with 
<line: 13> whom he was working on a different product told him about EKOBREW.  Tr. (Sep. 18, 
<line: 14> 2019) at 419:12-420:10 (docket no. 140).  Even if they were not aware of EKOBREW 
<line: 15> before seeking registration of ECO FILL, defendants knew about the competing mark 
<line: 16> several months before they introduced their similarly-named product into the market. 
<line: 17> 40. 
<line: 18> The haste with which Rivera applied to register ECO FILL also undermines 
<line: 19> his assertion that he was unaware of EKOBREW at the time.  Defendants could have 
<line: 20> ascertained from the PTO’s records that Eko Brands had been unsuccessful in its initial 
<line: 21> attempt to register EKOBREW, and the relative speed with which an application for 
<line: 22> ECO FILL was filed (less than two weeks after the ECO FILL logo was developed 
<line: 23> versus 6-to-10 years after using PERFECT POD in commerce) constitutes evidence of 
<line: 24> defendants’ desire to beat Eko Brands to the proverbial punch.  These facts demonstrate 

[ABANDON]
<line: 26> 1
<line: 27> 2
<line: 28> 3
<line: 29> 4
<line: 30> 5
<line: 31> 6
<line: 32> 7
<line: 33> 8
<line: 34> 9
<line: 35> 10
<line: 36> 11
<line: 37> 12
<line: 38> 13
<line: 39> 14
<line: 40> 15
<line: 41> 16
<line: 42> 17
<line: 43> 18
<line: 44> 19
<line: 45> 20
<line: 46> 21
<line: 47> 22
<line: 48> 23

[ABANDON]
<line: 50> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 19 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> I as the brand name for their new product..
<line: 3> 3
<line: 4> 6
<line: 5> 8.
<line: 6> 9 
<line: 7> 10  the designer was influenced by the EKOBREw logo. Moreover, the color choices for the
<line: 8> 11
<line: 9> 12
<line: 10>  tend to prove defendants copied, and therefore had knowledge of, Eko Brands' labeling.
<line: 11> 13
<line: 12> 14  the first claim of trademark infringement and the second claim of unfair competition,.
<line: 13> 15
<line: 14> 16 entitled to disgorgement of the profits attributable to such infringement.
<line: 15> 17
<line: 16> 18
<line: 17> 19
<line: 18> 20
<line: 19> 21
<line: 20> 22
<line: 21> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 23> circumstantially that defendants knew about EKOBREW when they adopted ECO FILL

[TEXT]
<line: 25> 41.
<line: 26> The progression in logo development further belies Rivera's denials..

[TEXT]
<line: 28> Although each of the three package concepts for EZ-FILL contained an image of a coffee
<line: 29> cup, none of the proposed logos for EZ-FILL incorporated a coffee cup or steam lines.
<line: 30> The first two concepts for EZ-FILL had no illustrative component, and the third idea
<line: 31> included a donut shape over a tapered cylinder, suggestive of the side view of an open
<line: 32> filter cartridge. In contrast, two of the designs for ECO FILL had coffee cups with steam
<line: 33> lines, and the third proposal had steam lines. This significant shift in style suggests that
<line: 34> ECO FILL logo, which mimic both the palette and the contrasts of the EKOBREW logo,

[TEXT]
<line: 36> 42.
<line: 37> The Court ADOPTS the advisory jury's verdict that, for purposes of both.
<line: 38> defendants' infringement was willful,10 and concludes that Eko Brands is therefore.

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 10 In light of the Court's finding of willfulness, the Court need not address defendants' argument
<line: 41> that Eko Brands' claims are barred by the equitable doctrine of laches. See Danjaq LLC v. Sony
<line: 42> Corp., 263 F.3d 942, 956 (9th Cir. 2001) (observing, in the copyright context, that "laches does
<line: 43> not bar a suit against a deliberate infringer'); see also Nat'l Lead Co. v. Wolfe, 223 F.2d 195, 202
<line: 44> (9th Cir. 1955) ("In the light of the intentional and fraudulent use of appellant's trade mark, the
<line: 45> [laches] defense here is a frivolous one." (citing Menendez v. Holt, 128 U.S. 514, 523 (1888)));
<line: 46> Fitbug Ltd. v. Fitbit, Inc., 78 F. Supp. 3d 1180, 1195-96 (N.D. Cal. 2015) (declining to apply the
<line: 47> "piracy' exception to laches because the infringement at issue was not willful).

[ABANDON]
<line: 49> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 20

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TITLE]
<line: 26> F. 
<line: 27> Disgorgement of Profits 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 43. 
<line: 30> With respect to the first claim for trademark infringement, Eko Brands may 
<line: 31> recover any profits earned by defendants on or after November 1, 2016, that are 
<line: 32> attributable to the infringement.  With respect to the second claim for unfair competition, 
<line: 33> Eko Brands may recover any profits of defendants that are attributable to the unfair 
<line: 34> competition, subject to the following limitations:  (i) Eko Brands may not recover any 
<line: 35> such profits earned before defendants had actual notice that Eko Brands was using the 
<line: 36> EKOBREW Marks; and (ii) Eko Brands may not recover any such profits earned on or 
<line: 37> after November 1, 2016.  Court’s Instruction No. 18; see Coach, Inc. v. Asia Pac. 
<line: 38> Trading Co., 676 F. Supp. 2d 914, 924-25 (C.D. Cal. 2009). 

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 44. 
<line: 41> Profit is determined by deducting all expenses from gross revenue.  Gross 
<line: 42> revenue is all of defendants’ receipts from sales of products bearing infringing marks.  
<line: 43> Expenses are all operating, overhead, and production costs incurred in producing the 
<line: 44> gross revenue.  Eko Brands has the burden of proving defendants’ gross revenue by a 
<line: 45> preponderance of the evidence.  Defendants have the burden of proving their expenses, 
<line: 46> as well as the portion of their profit attributable to factors other than the use of infringing 
<line: 47> marks, by a preponderance of the evidence.  9th Cir. Model Instr. No. 15.29; see 15 
<line: 48> U.S.C. § 1117(a). 

[TEXT]
<line: 50> 45. 
<line: 51> Eko Brands seeks the following amounts as “profit” earned by defendants: 

[TEXT]
<line: 53> Claim 1 
<line: 54> November 1, 2016 - July 31, 2019 
<line: 55> $    439,075.50 
<line: 56> August 1, 2019 - present 
<line: 57> $      57,092.00 
<line: 58>  per month 

[TEXT]
<line: 60> Claim 2 
<line: 61> January 1, 2012 - October 31, 2016 
<line: 62> $ 5,618,371.50 

[ABANDON]
<line: 64> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 21 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> Defendants offer five reasons why Eko Brands is not entitled to the requested sums, 
<line: 27> namely (i) Eko Brands already recovered a portion of these figures in connection with 
<line: 28> previous patent litigation between the parties; (ii) a portion of the profit is not attributable 
<line: 29> to trademark infringement or unfair competition but rather to the ECO FILL product’s 
<line: 30> compatibility with the new Keurig® 2.0 machine; (iii) the amount sought for the period 
<line: 31> from August 1, 2019, to the present is unsupported by any evidence; (iv) the sums 
<line: 32> proposed by Eko Brands fail to take into account expenses proven by defendants; and 
<line: 33> (v) the decline in EKOBREW sales, which began in 2013, was not caused by defendants’ 
<line: 34> use of similar marks but rather by Eko Brands’ introduction of a cheaper version of its 
<line: 35> reusable filter product under a different brand, namely BREW & SAVE. 

[TITLE]
<line: 37> a. 
<line: 38> Prior Patent Litigation  

[TEXT]
<line: 40> 46. 
<line: 41> In Eko Brands, LLC v. Adrian Rivera Maynez Enterprises, Inc., et al., 
<line: 42> W.D. Wash. Case No. C15-522 JPD, a jury awarded damages to Eko Brands and against 
<line: 43> ARM and Rivera in the amount of $192,801.00 for non-willful infringement of United 
<line: 44> States Patent No. 8,707,855 (the “’855 Patent”).  See Verdict (C15-522, docket no. 242).  
<line: 45> The products alleged to infringe the ’855 Patent were ARM’s reusable filters branded as 
<line: 46> ECO-FILL DELUXE (also known as ECO FILL 1.0 - 2 pack), ECO-FILL DELUXE 2.0 
<line: 47> (also known as ECO FILL 2.0), ECO-FLOW v1, and ECO-FLOW v2.  See Pretrial Order 
<line: 48> at ¶ II.1 (C15-522, docket no. 218).  The jury was instructed that the commencement date 
<line: 49> for damages was April 2, 2015.  Instr. No. 39 (C15-522, docket no. 233).  The amount 
<line: 50> of damages reflected the reasonable royalty that the jury found would compensate Eko 

[ABANDON]
<line: 52> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 22 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> Brands for the patent infringement at issue, through the date of the verdict, which was 
<line: 23> June 8, 2018.  See Instr. Nos. 36-38 (C15-522, docket no. 233). 
<line: 24> 47. 
<line: 25> During his opening statement in the patent trial, counsel for Eko Brands 
<line: 26> told the jury that the claim for infringement of the ’855 Patent “covers the entirety of this 
<line: 27> unit,” meaning ARM’s ECO FILL and/or ECO-FLOW capsule, and that Eko Brands is 
<line: 28> “entitled to the royalty based on that unit.”  Tr. (June 4, 2018) at 65:19-22 (C15-522, 
<line: 29> docket no. 326).  According to Eko Brands’ attorney, the features of ARM’s product 
<line: 30> could not be apportioned so as to reduce the royalty rate, and the unit was “not divisible 
<line: 31> in any other way.”  Id. at 65:15-23.  In his opening statement in the trademark matter, the 
<line: 32> same lawyer for Eko Brands explained disgorgement as follows:  “Remember that graph, 
<line: 33> the inverse relationship as Eko’s profits went down . . . , defendants’ went up.  And it’s 
<line: 34> that delta there, or the disgorgement of profits that trademark law allows [Eko Brands] to 
<line: 35> recover.”  Tr. (Sep. 16, 2019) at 21:22-22:1 (docket no. 138).11   
<line: 36> 48. 
<line: 37> To the extent Eko Brands alleges that defendants’ profit in connection with 
<line: 38> the ECO FILL and ECO-FLOW products was attributable exclusively to trademark 
<line: 39> infringement, such theory runs contrary to the premise on which the jury in the patent 
<line: 40> case awarded damages, i.e., that defendants profited from infringing the ’855 Patent 
<line: 41> without paying a reasonable royalty.  The patent royalty owed by defendants, which 
<line: 42> constitutes an item of expense to be deducted from gross revenue to compute net profit, 

[ABANDON]
<line: 44> 11 To the extent Eko Brands contends that it is entitled to both its losses (decline in profit), as 
<line: 45> well as defendants’ profit, such assertion is inconsistent with Eko Brands’ withdrawal of its 
<line: 46> claim for actual damages.  See Pla.’s Resp. (docket no. 120). 

[ABANDON]
<line: 48> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 23 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> cannot now be ignored without resulting in double recovery.  Moreover, Eko Brands will 
<line: 3> not be permitted in equity to argue that, for purposes of disgorgement under the Lanham 
<line: 4> Act, branding is all that matters when, in the patent context, it took the position that the 
<line: 5> various product features, including the labeling, were not divisible.  The Court therefore 
<line: 6> concludes that Eko Brands is not entitled, in connection with either claim in this action, 
<line: 7> to disgorgement of defendants’ profit associated with products bearing the marks ECO 
<line: 8> FILL DELUXE, ECO FILL DELUXE 2.0, or ECO-FLOW during the period from 
<line: 9> April 2, 2015, through June 8, 2018, for which Eko Brands was awarded damages in the 
<line: 10> patent litigation.12 

[TITLE]
<line: 12> b. 
<line: 13> Compatibility With Keurig® 2.0 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> 49. 
<line: 16> In early 2014, defendants became aware that Keurig was planning to 
<line: 17> introduce a new brewing machine with a security feature that would inhibit the use of 
<line: 18> non-Keurig cartridges unless they were officially licensed.  Prior to the launch of the 
<line: 19> Keurig® 2.0 machine, ARM’s Vice President Dino Ditta was able to obtain a sample and, 
<line: 20> upon investigation, determined that the security feature was ink or color based.  Thus, 
<line: 21> when Keurig® 2.0 was placed on the market in October 2014, ARM was ready with a 
<line: 22> compatible product.  Prior to the introduction of the Keurig® 2.0 machine, ARM had a 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> 12 Both sides have appealed from the judgment in the patent litigation, and the matter remains 
<line: 25> pending before the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit.  Any reversal or 
<line: 26> modification of such judgment by the Federal Circuit would have minimal effect on the award of 
<line: 27> profit in this matter for two reasons:  (i) ARM sustained net losses during most of the period for 
<line: 28> which Eko Brands was awarded patent royalties; and (ii) a separate basis exists for excluding the 
<line: 29> profit related to ECO-FILL DELUXE 2.0 (ECO-FILL 2.0), as explained in the next subsection. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 31> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 24 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> relatively low volume of sales of ECO FILL capsules.  After Keurig® 2.0 arrived on the 
<line: 27> market, ARM’s ECO FILL related revenues soared. 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 51. 
<line: 30> As reflected in Chart 1, ARM’s gross revenue for ECO FILL branded 
<line: 31> products drastically increased shortly after Keurig® 2.0 machines began selling, when the 
<line: 32> ECO FILL filter was one of very few options for Keurig’s new device, but as Eko Brands 
<line: 33> and other competitors also started offering Keurig® 2.0 compatible cartridges, ARM’s 
<line: 34> market share substantially declined.

[TEXT]
<line: 73> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 25 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 52. 
<line: 3> The correlation between ARM’s ECO FILL related gross revenues and its 
<line: 4> status as the first, and, for a brief period, only, manufacturer (other than Keurig) with an 
<line: 5> operable reusable filter for Keurig® 2.0 machines is convincing circumstantial evidence 
<line: 6> that defendants’ profit associated with the ECO FILL 2.0 product is attributable to a 
<line: 7> factor other than trademark infringement and/or unfair competition.13  The Court 
<line: 8> therefore DECLINES to adopt the advisory jury’s calculation of profit to be disgorged. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 10> 1
<line: 11> 2
<line: 12> 3
<line: 13> 4
<line: 14> 5
<line: 15> 6
<line: 16> 7
<line: 17> 8
<line: 18> 9
<line: 19> 10
<line: 20> 11

<line: 22> 13
<line: 23> 14
<line: 24> 15

<line: 29> 20
<line: 30> 21
<line: 31> 22
<line: 32> 23

[TITLE]
<line: 34> c. 
<line: 35> Insufficiency of Evidence 

[TEXT]
<line: 37> 53. 
<line: 38> With regard to defendants’ profit for the period from August 1, 2019, to the 
<line: 39> present, Eko Brands did not satisfy its burden of proving gross revenue.  The amount 
<line: 40> sought for the approximately six-week period before trial and thereafter (i.e., $57,092.00 
<line: 41> per month) is entirely speculative, extrapolated from variable monthly profit figures for 
<line: 42> the preceding years without any expert (or even lay) testimony to support such analysis.  
<line: 43> Eko Brands is not entitled to disgorgement of defendants’ profit on or after August 1, 
<line: 44> 2019. 

[TEXT]
<line: 46> 13 Defendants offered a similar explanation concerning ARM’s ECO CARAFE filter, indicating 
<line: 47> that Eko Brands’ similar carafe-sized product also had compatibility issues with the Keurig® 2.0 
<line: 48> machine, but in contrast to the testimony concerning the ECO FILL 2.0 device, defendants did 
<line: 49> not provide evidence concerning the timing of the changes Keurig made to the security system, 
<line: 50> which necessitated a redesign of the carafe cartridge, or the monthly sales before and after ARM 
<line: 51> rolled out its solution.  As a result, the Court cannot draw the same conclusion with respect to 
<line: 52> ECO CARAFE as it has in connection with ECO FILL 2.0, and instead concludes that 
<line: 53> defendants have not met their burden of proving that any portion of the profit derived from use 
<line: 54> of the mark ECO CARAFE is attributable to the ARM product’s superior compatibility with 
<line: 55> Keurig’s 2.0 device. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 57> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 26 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TITLE]
<line: 26> d. 
<line: 27> Expenses 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 54. 
<line: 30> In attempting to meet their burden of proving expenses, defendants relied 
<line: 31> on financial summaries provided in a spreadsheet format.  See Exs. 89 & 274.  The 
<line: 32> spreadsheets itemized expenses on a yearly basis, and they divided the annual overhead 
<line: 33> between the “ECO” part and the remainder of ARM’s business.  Defendants have 
<line: 34> proffered sufficient evidence to support the expenses that must be deducted from gross 
<line: 35> revenue in calculating the profit to be disgorged. 

[TEXT]
<line: 37> 55. 
<line: 38> Given the need to apportion the profit between Eko Brands’ two claims, 
<line: 39> which involve different sets of infringing marks and distinct time frames, the Court has 
<line: 40> used the data set forth in Exhibit 274, which is duplicated in Exhibit 89, to allocate 
<line: 41> “ECO” related expenses pro rata among the various marks.  The pro rata computation 
<line: 42> was performed on the basis of gross profit (gross revenue minus cost of goods).  For 
<line: 43> example, in 2014, the gross profit generated by ECO FILL 1.0 ($148,777 + $280,446) 
<line: 44> and ECO FILL MAX ($10,317) capsules was $439,540.  This figure represents roughly 
<line: 45> 52% of the gross profit for all “ECO” products ($841,628), and thus, 52% of the “ECO” 
<line: 46> related expenses (or $233,634 of the total $447,360) was deducted to arrive at a net profit 
<line: 47> figure of $205,906 for ECO FILL 1.0 and ECO FILL MAX products combined (referred 
<line: 48> to in Tables 1 and 2, infra ¶¶ 59 & 60, as simply “ECO FILL 1.0”).  This analysis was 
<line: 49> performed for each brand and year at issue. 

[TITLE]
<line: 51> e. 
<line: 52> Cannibalization 

[TEXT]
<line: 54> 56. 
<line: 55> In 2012 or 2013, Eko Brands began offering a reusable filter under the 
<line: 56> mark BREW & SAVE.  The BREW & SAVE cartridge is lower in price than the 

[ABANDON]
<line: 58> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 27 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> comparable EKOBREW capsule, and the two products are or were sold in different aisles.
<line: 3> 2of the same stores. By 2014, the revenue generated by Eko Brands' BREW & SAVE
<line: 4> 3 devices rivaled that of its EKOBREW filters. In 2015, BREW & SAVE sales declined,.
<line: 5> while those of EKOBREW began to rebound. The combined revenue on EKOBREW
<line: 6> 5 and BREW & SAVE goods remained roughly constant from 2013 through 2015,
<line: 7> hovering in the range of $5 million annually

[ABANDON]
<line: 9> 7
<line: 10> 8
<line: 11> 9
<line: 12> 10
<line: 13> 11

<line: 45> 57.
<line: 46> Although counsel for Eko Brands asserted in closing argument that this
<line: 47> cannibalization" does not explain the drop in EKOBREW's revenue, Eko Brands' own.

[TEXT]
<line: 49> 14 In 2012, Eko Brands began marketing its filters to other companies like Rockline Industries,
<line: 50> which has since offered the capsules manufactured by Eko Brands under the *Brew Rite"' label..
<line: 51> SuperValu, Inc., which offers various goods under the Essential Everyday trademark, and the
<line: 52> country's largest supermarket chain, the Kroger Company, which has several in-store brands.
<line: 53> See Ex. 149 at 19; see also www.supervalu.com; www.kroger.com. The revenue generated by

[ABANDON]
<line: 55> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 28

[TEXT]
<line: 2> evidence undermines his position. According to an April 2014 management presentation,.
<line: 3>  admitted as Exhibit 149, Eko Brands did not experience much growth in revenue between
<line: 4> 2012 and 2013, but the shares attributable to Eko Brands' "private label"' (e.g., Kroger,
<line: 5> Brew Rite," Essential Everyday) business and BREW & SAVE products increased
<line: 6> significantly, from 5.5% to 14.9% and from 3.1% to 9.8%, respectively. At the same
<line: 7> 6 time, the percentage of sales generated by EKOBREW goods dropped from 91.4% to
<line: 8> 71.5%. This data shows that, at least during the period when defendants first began using.
<line: 9> the ECO FILL mark, the first in their line of similar marks, cannibalization (in contrast
<line: 10> 9 to defendants' unfair competition) was a significant factor in EKOBREW's declining.
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12>  sales. 15

<line: 42> damages, it would not have been able to prove at trial any losses caused by defendants' unfair
<line: 43> competition and/or trademark infringement.

<line: 45> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 29

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 2

<line: 5> base any diminution of the amount to be disgorged on such cannibalization, but it will
<line: 6> 8

<line: 23> 58.

<line: 25> which cannibalization constitutes a reason other than trademark infringement and/or.
<line: 26> unfair competition for ARM's accrual of profit in connection with its ECO FILL, ECO
<line: 27> CARAFE, ECO-FLOW, and related products. Absent a quantified correlation between
<line: 28> consider the subject in connection with the injunctive relief that Eko Brands seeks...

[TITLE]
<line: 30> Calculation of Award

[TEXT]
<line: 32> 59.
<line: 33> For the foregoing reasons, the Court reaches a different result than the.
<line: 34> respect to Eko Brands' first claim for trademark infringement, the Court's analysis is as
<line: 35> follows:

[TITLE]
<line: 37> Table 1: CLAIM 1 (Trademark Infringement)
<line: 38> Defendants' Profits to Be Disgorged

<line: 72> 16 No product bearing the mark ECO FILL DELUXE (or ECO FILL DELUXE 1.0, as opposed
<line: 73> to ECO FILL DELUXE 2.0) was sold during the period specified. See Ex. 274.

[ABANDON]
<line: 75> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 30

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> 60. 
<line: 27> As for Eko Brands’ second claim alleging unfair competition, further 
<line: 28> discussion is warranted concerning the profit associated with defendants’ use of the mark 
<line: 29> ECO CARAFE.  Although Eko Brands’ co-owner Laura Sommers approximated that, 
<line: 30> in 2015, Eko Brands began selling carafe-size filters under the EKOBREW Marks, she 
<line: 31> admitted during cross-examination that she did not know which company, ARM or 
<line: 32> Eko Brands, was the first to launch a carafe product.  See Tr. (Sep. 16, 2019) at 66:13-15 
<line: 33> (docket no. 138);  Tr. (Sep. 17, 2019) at 163:11-16 (docket no. 139).  Other evidence, 
<line: 34> including facts stipulated by the parties, indicates that ARM entered the carafe market in 
<line: 35> early February 2015, while Eko Brands trailed far behind and did not introduce a carafe 
<line: 36> device until March 2016.  During the interim, defendants generated a profit of $822,290 
<line: 37> on sales of ECO CARAFE filters.17  For three consecutive years beginning in 2016, when 
<line: 38> Eko Brands began offering a carafe filter carrying the EKOBREW Marks, defendants 
<line: 39> experienced net losses.  The Court finds that the profit associated with use of the mark 
<line: 40> ECO CARAFE during the time frame of Claim 2 is attributable to a factor other than 
<line: 41> unfair competition, namely the absence of any competing EKOBREW carafe-size 
<line: 42> product.  In light of this and other rulings, the Court concludes that the amount of profit 
<line: 43> to be disgorged by defendants, in connection with Eko Brands’ second claim for unfair 
<line: 44> competition, is as follows: 

[TEXT]
<line: 46> 17 In 2015, the gross profit associated with ECO CARAFE was $1,536,966.  Ex. 274.  This 
<line: 47> amount represented about 27.2% of the gross profit in 2015 for “ECO” products in the aggregate 
<line: 48> ($5,657,602).  Subtracting a pro rata share of the expenses for 2015 ($714,676 = $2,630,738 x 
<line: 49> (1,536,966 ÷ 5,657,602)) yields a net profit of $822,290 for ECO CARAFE devices in 2015. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 51> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 31
