<line: 46> 0 18
<line: 47> TOTAL
<line: 48> $ 515,148

[TITLE]
<line: 50> Injunctive Relief.

[TEXT]
<line: 52> 61.
<line: 53> Eko Brands seeks a permanent injunction prohibiting defendants from.
<line: 54> using the marks ECO FILL (including ECO FILL DELUXE, ECO FILL DELUXE 2.0,
<line: 55> and ECO FILL MAX), ECO CARAFE, ECO-FLOW, ECO-PURE, ECO FILTER, and
<line: 56> ECOSAVE or any similar marks, and requiring defendants to deliver for destruction all.
<line: 57> advertising materials, products, labels and packaging, and business materials bearing.
<line: 58> such marks. The Lanham Act invests the Court with the "power to grant injunctions,.
<line: 59> according to the principles of equity and upon such terms as the court may deem
<line: 60> reasonable, to prevent the violation of any right"' of the owner of a registered trademark.
<line: 61> 15 U.S.C.  1116(a). To be entitled to such relief, Eko Brands must prove (i) it has.
<line: 62> suffered an irreparable injury; (ii) remedies available at law, like monetary damages, are.
<line: 63> not adequate to compensate for such injury; (iii) the balance of hardships weighs in favor
<line: 64> of granting the requested remedy in equity; and (iv) the public interest would not be.

[TEXT]
<line: 66> initiated the patent litigation involving ECO-FLOW (and ECO FILL) products. Thus, for the
<line: 67>  period indicated, no profit related to ECO-FLOW was generated or is required be disgorged.

[ABANDON]
<line: 69> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 32

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> | disserved by the imposition of a permanent injunction. See Reno Air Racing Ass'n, Inc.
<line: 3> 3
<line: 4> 5
<line: 5> 6.
<line: 6> 9
<line: 7> 10  Irreparable injury might consist of the loss of control over business reputation and/or
<line: 8> 11
<line: 9> 12
<line: 10> 13
<line: 11> 14i
<line: 12> 16  that it actually had' (emphasis in original).
<line: 13> 17
<line: 14> 19
<line: 15> 20 Brands' goodwill, Eko Brands relies merely on the "erosion' of EKOBREW sales. Pla.'s
<line: 16> 211
<line: 17> 22
<line: 18> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 20> v. McCord, 452 F.3d 1126, 1137-38 & n.11 (9th Cir. 2006).
<line: 21> 62.
<line: 22>  To establish irreparable injury, Eko Brands must "do more than merely
<line: 23>  demonstrate that a trademark has been infringed or that consumers have been confused."'
<line: 24> See San Miguel Pure Foods Co. v. Ramar Int'l Corp., 625 Fed. App'x 322, 327 (9th Cir.
<line: 25> 2015); see also Herb Reed Enters., LLC y. Fla. Entm't Mgmt., Inc., 736 F.3d 1239, 1250
<line: 26> (9th Cir. 2013) ("Gone are the days when [o]nce the plaintiff in an infringement action
<line: 27> has established a likelihood of confusion, it is ordinarily presumed that the plaintiff will
<line: 28> suffer irreparable harm if injunctive relief does not issue.'" (alteration in original))
<line: 29> damage to goodwill, but such harm must be grounded in evidence, not "platitudes," and it
<line: 30> may not be presumed from infringement alone or based on speculation. See Herb Reed,
<line: 31> 736 F.3d at 1250; see also San Miguel, 625 Fed. App'x at 327-28 (vacating a permanent
<line: 32> injunction, reasoning that the district court's finding of irreparable harm was premised on
<line: 33> speculation that the trademark owner "would effectively lose control" over its brand, "not
<line: 34> 63.
<line: 35>  Eko Brands has not made the requisite showing of irreparable injury to.
<line: 36> warrant the type of broad injunctive relief it has requested. In asserting that defendants'
<line: 37> infringement has taken Eko Brands' "reputation out of its own hands" and "eroded" Eko
<line: 38> Proposed Findings & Conclusions at 25,  101 (docket no. 144). The decline in revenue
<line: 39> generated by EKOBREW products is, however, explained by the concomitant success of

[ABANDON]
<line: 41> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 33

[ABANDON]
<line: 2>  that EKOBREW's reduction in earnings is primarily the result of cannibalization, rather
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 5 I
<line: 5> 6
<line: 6> 8
<line: 7> 10
<line: 8> 11
<line: 9> 12
<line: 10> 13
<line: 11> 14
<line: 12> 15
<line: 13> 16
<line: 14> 17
<line: 15> 18
<line: 16> 19
<line: 17> 20
<line: 18> 21
<line: 19> 22
<line: 20> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 22> Eko Brands' "private label'" and BREW & SAVE businesses. Eko Brands has not refuted
<line: 23> than infringement, and it has not presented any evidence concerning the historical or
<line: 24> current market shares of EKOBREW and ARM products, respectively.19 Instead, Eko.
<line: 25> Brands relies on the types of platitudes, presumptions, and speculations that the United.
<line: 26> States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has routinely rejected in considering the
<line: 27> appropriateness of injunctive relief.

[TEXT]
<line: 29> 64.
<line: 30> In 2016, 2017, and 2018, the "ECO" part of ARM's business suffered net.
<line: 31> losses, while Eko Brands' EKOBREW products generated revenue in those same years of

[TEXT]
<line: 33> 19 At trial, counsel for Eko Brands offered Exhibit 80, which sets forth Eko Brands' and its
<line: 34> competitors' market shares for the year ending February 25, 2017, but defendants' hearsay
<line: 35> objection was sustained, and Exhibit 80 was not admitted. See Tr. (Sep. 18, 2019) at 365:2-18
<line: 36> (docket no. 140). Eko Brands marked for identification, but did not offer, Exhibit 129, which
<line: 37> reports market shares for the year ending January 26, 2019. Even if such evidence had been
<line: 38> admitted, it would not have supported Eko Brands' assertion of irreparable harm because it
<line: 39> indicates that, while ARM's share remained fairly steady, Eko Brands lost considerable ground
<line: 40> to Keurig. In other words, Exhibits 80 and 129 suggest that defendants' infringement did not
<line: 41>  cause Eko Brands' loss of sales during the three-year period (February 25, 2016 - January 29,
<line: 42> 2019) shortly preceding trial in this matter. The Court therefore concludes that no purpose
<line: 43> would be served by allowing Eko Brands to supplement the record or present further argument in
<line: 44> support of its request for injunctive relief..

[FIGURE_CAPTION]
<line: 46> Year Ending February 25, 2017

[FIGURE_CAPTION]
<line: 48> Year Ending January 26, 2019

[FIGURE]
<line: 50> 20.7%
<line: 51> 42.4%
<line: 52> 29.4%
<line: 53> 7.5%
<line: 54> -Eko Brands - Keurig - ARM - All Other

[FIGURE]
<line: 56> 34.9%
<line: 57> 40.4%
<line: 58> 6.1%
<line: 59> 18.6%
<line: 60> - Eko Brands - Keurig - ARM - All Other

[ABANDON]
<line: 62> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 34

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23
<line: 25> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 35 
<line: 26> $4.4 million, $3 million, and $2.7 million, respectively.  See Ex. 274; Tr. (Sep. 18, 2019) 
<line: 27> at 369:21-22 (docket no. 140).  Although the figures decreased over the three-year span, 
<line: 28> the sheer quantity of sales belies any sense that Eko Brands has suffered irreparable harm 
<line: 29> to its reputation or goodwill.  Moreover, to the extent confusion between EKOBREW and 
<line: 30> defendants’ “ECO” marks has occurred, Eko Brands has not identified any comments 
<line: 31> that were derogatory of the parties’ respective products nor proven that any EKOBREW 
<line: 32> customer was lost to ARM.  See San Miguel, 625 Fed. App’x at 327.  Eko Brands has not 
<line: 33> shown that defendants’ attempt to exploit the early success of the EKOBREW Marks has 
<line: 34> caused Eko Brands to lose control over its reputation or impacted Eko Brands’ goodwill 
<line: 35> in a manner that has not been compensated by monetary relief. 
<line: 36> 65. 
<line: 37> Eko Brands has, however, demonstrated a significant risk that defendants 
<line: 38> will continue to engage in infringing conduct and that, if defendants are not restricted in 
<line: 39> some manner with respect to the use of “ECO” in their marks, the parties will continue to 
<line: 40> be embroiled in litigation until one or the other or both of them are driven out of business.  
<line: 41> See Anhing Corp. v. Thuan Phong Co., 2015 WL 4517846 at *24 (C.D. Cal. July 24, 
<line: 42> 2015) (observing that injunctive relief avoids giving an infringer “a judicially imposed 
<line: 43> compulsory license” and alleviates the burden on the trademark owner of “filing 
<line: 44> duplicative lawsuits”).  This prospect establishes a form of irreparable injury, as well as 
<line: 45> the inadequacy of damages alone.  It also tips the balance of hardships in favor of some 
<line: 46> injunctive relief and indicates that the public interest in avoiding market confusion and 
<line: 47> efficiently expending judicial resources will be served by limiting defendants’ conduct.  
<line: 48> The Court therefore concludes that a permanent injunction is appropriate, but it must be 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> tailored much more narrowly than Eko Brands has proposed.  In determining the scope of 
<line: 3> injunctive relief, the Court may consider a number of factors, including (i) the nature of 
<line: 4> the interest to be protected, (ii) the nature and extent of the wrongful conduct, (iii) the 
<line: 5> relative harm likely to result to the legitimate interests of the parties if an injunction is 
<line: 6> granted or denied, and (iv) the practicality of framing and enforcing an injunction.  See 
<line: 7> Quiksilver, Inc. v. Kymsta Corp., 360 Fed. App’x 886, 889-90 (9th Cir. 2009); see also 
<line: 8> Restatement (Third) of Unfair Competition § 35 (1995) (cited in Quiksilver). 
<line: 9> 66. 
<line: 10> Given (i) the relative weakness of the EKOBREW Marks, and the long 
<line: 11> period of coexistence in the market, during which only three isolated instances of 
<line: 12> confusion have been identified, and (ii) defendants’ extension of the “ECO” line of marks 
<line: 13> (from ECO FILL to ECO CARAFE and ECO-FLOW) during a time when Eko Brands 
<line: 14> had not yet been successful in registering the EKOBREW Marks, Eko Brands’ proposal 
<line: 15> to preclude defendants from using, in connection with coffee products, “ECO” or “EKO” 
<line: 16> alone or in combination with other words or symbols in a service mark, trademark, trade 
<line: 17> name, or domain name is overly broad.  A permanent injunction containing these terms 
<line: 18> (iii) would likely signal the death knell of ARM’s business involving reusable filters and 
<line: 19> related products, while having minimal or no positive effect on Eko Brands’ market 
<line: 20> position, and (iv) might be difficult to enforce in light of the myriad ways in which the 
<line: 21> letters “ECO” or “EKO” could be incorporated into brands or website addresses without 
<line: 22> connoting the environmental conscientiousness underlying the EKOBREW Marks, 
<line: 23> for example, ECONOMY, EKOCHAMBER (a phonetic equivalent of “echo chamber”), 
<line: 24> BEKON (a phonetic equivalent of “beckon”), DÉCOR, RECOVER, or ZYDECO. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 26> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 36 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 2 things "ECO,"' the Court is able to craft a more limited permanent injunction that strikes
<line: 3> 3 the proper balance between Eko Brands' right to use its EKOBREW Marks without fear
<line: 4> 5  beverage filter industry. Eko Brands' request for a permanent injunction is therefore
<line: 5> 6.
<line: 6> to the EKOBREw Marks in a manner that is likely to cause confusion concerning the
<line: 7> 9  source of the goods. Defendants may not use "EKO' as the initial letters of a mark, but
<line: 8> 10  they may continue to use ECO' as a prefix or other component of a mark, provided they.
<line: 9> 11
<line: 10> 12  the product. To comply with this directive, defendants may combine their "non-ECO".
<line: 11> 13
<line: 12> 14
<line: 13> 15
<line: 14> 16
<line: 15> 17
<line: 16> 18
<line: 17> 19
<line: 18> 20
<line: 19> 21
<line: 20> 22 
<line: 21> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 23> 67.  Although Eko Brands has offered no alternative to its blanket ban on all.
<line: 24>  of consumer confusion and defendants' interests in continuing to compete in the reusable
<line: 25> GRANTED in part and DENIED in part as follows. Defendants ARM and Adrian Rivera
<line: 26> are permanently enjoined from using, in connection with coffee products, marks similar
<line: 27> include in close proximity another trademark or trade name that makes clear the source of
<line: 28> and "ECO" marks or logos in a variety of ways, for example, "ECO FILL, a product of
<line: 29> Adrian Rivera Maynez Enterprises, Inc.," "ECO FILL from PERFECT POD," or perhaps
<line: 30> a mix of designs, as follows:.

[FIGURE]
<line: 32> ECO-FILL
<line: 33> SINGLE SERVE FILTERS by ARM Enterprises, Inc.

[TEXT]
<line: 35> Defendants are not required to adopt any of these suggestions, but they must deploy at
<line: 36> least one "non-ECO" brand or business identifier in connection with each "ECO" mark

[ABANDON]
<line: 38> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 37

[TEXT]
<line: 2> as a method of substantially reducing or eliminating the likelihood of confusion with the 
<line: 3> EKOBREW Marks. 
<line: 4> 68. 
<line: 5> Defendants shall modify their website and all electronic marketing means 
<line: 6> accordingly within six (6) weeks after entry of judgment in this matter, but defendants 
<line: 7> will be allowed to use their current supply of printed advertising materials and to sell off 
<line: 8> their existing inventory of “ECO” products through June 30, 2020.  Any “old ECO logo” 
<line: 9> advertising materials or products remaining after the sell-off period shall be immediately 
<line: 10> destroyed.  This permanent injunction shall be binding on defendants and all of their 
<line: 11> officers, agents, and employees, as well as on all persons who are in active concert or 
<line: 12> participation with defendants and have received actual notice of this permanent 
<line: 13> injunction.  The terms of this permanent injunction shall be set forth in the Judgment to 
<line: 14> be entered by the Clerk.  Defendants shall provide a copy of the Judgment to their 
<line: 15> officers, agents, and employees, and to any package, label, or logo designers or graphic 
<line: 16> artists working on a contract basis with defendants.  If, after the sell-off period, any 
<line: 17> manufacturing facilities, warehousing companies, shipping entities, wholesalers, 
<line: 18> distributors, retailers, or licensees are in possession of “old ECO logo” advertising 
<line: 19> materials, packaging, labels, and/or products, defendants shall provide a copy of the 
<line: 20> Judgment to such persons.  By July 15, 2020, defendants shall file a status report, verified 
<line: 21> by a sworn declaration, indicating the steps they have taken to comply with the 
<line: 22> permanent injunction.  Eko Brands may, but is not required to, file a response to the 
<line: 23> status report within fourteen (14) days after it is filed.  The Court will retain jurisdiction 

[ABANDON]
<line: 25> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 38 

[ABANDON]

<line: 4> and 5,741,858 (ECO FILTER) is DENIED.20

[TITLE]
<line: 23> Conclusion

[TEXT]
<line: 25> follows:
<line: 26> a.
<line: 27> The Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to 28 U.S.C. $ 1338;
<line: 28> b.
<line: 29> The EKOBREW Marks are valid because they are either inherently.
<line: 30> distinctive or they have acquired secondary meaning, and Eko Brands
<line: 31> owned the EKOBREW Marks before defendants began using ECO FILL;
<line: 32> c.
<line: 33> Defendants' use of ECO FILL, ECO CARAFE, ECO-FLOW, ECO
<line: 34> FILTER, ECOSAVE, and ECO-PURE on products similar to those sold by
<line: 35> Eko Brands under the EKOBREW Marks is likely to cause confusion about
<line: 36> the source of the respective goods;
<line: 37> d.
<line: 38> Defendants' adoption of the ECO FILL mark, the first of their "ECO"' style
<line: 39> marks, was willful;.
<line: 40> e.
<line: 41> In light of Eko Brands' award of royalties in the parties' earlier patent
<line: 42> litigation, Eko Brands is not entitled to disgorgement of defendants' profit

[ABANDON]
<line: 44> 20 Eko Brands seeks an order "cancelling' ARM's pending applications to register ECOSAVE
<line: 45> and the ecdsave design. The Court is without jurisdiction to grant such relief. See Whitney.
<line: 46> Info. Network, Inc. v. Gagnon, 353 F. Supp. 2d 1208, 1211 (M.D. Fla. 2005); GMA Accessories,
<line: 47> Inc. v. Idea Nuova, Inc., 157 F. Supp. 2d 234, 241 (S.D.N.Y. 2000); see also 15 U.S.C. $ 1119.

[ABANDON]
<line: 49> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 39

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23

[TEXT]
<line: 26> associated with products bearing the marks ECO FILL DELUXE, ECO 
<line: 27> FILL DELUXE 2.0, or ECO-FLOW during the period from April 2, 2015, 
<line: 28> through June 8, 2018; 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> f. 
<line: 31> Eko Brands is not entitled to disgorgement of any of defendants’ profit in 
<line: 32> connection with ECO FILL DELUXE 2.0 (or ECO FILL 2.0) because 
<line: 33> defendants carried their burden of proving that such profit is attributable to 
<line: 34> a factor other than trademark infringement or unfair competition, namely 
<line: 35> the ECO FILL 2.0 product’s compatibility with the Keurig® 2.0 machine; 
<line: 36> g. 
<line: 37> Eko Brands is not entitled to disgorgement of defendants’ profit for the 
<line: 38> period from August 1, 2019, to the present because it did not satisfy its 
<line: 39> burden of proving gross revenue; 
<line: 40> h. 
<line: 41> On Claim 2, Eko Brands is not entitled to disgorgement of defendants’ 
<line: 42> profit related to the ECO CARAFE product (a net of $822,290 in 2015) 
<line: 43> because it did not contemporaneously have a competing carafe-size filter;  
<line: 44> i. 
<line: 45> Eko Brands is entitled to the following amounts, reflecting the profit to be 
<line: 46> disgorged by defendants: 

[TEXT]
<line: 48> Claim 1 (trademark infringement)  
<line: 49> $ 134,040 
<line: 50> Claim 2 (unfair competition) 
<line: 51> $ 515,148 
<line: 52> TOTAL: 
<line: 53> $ 649,188 

[TEXT]
<line: 55> Eko Brands has withdrawn its earlier request for prejudgment interest; see 
<line: 56> Pla.’s Resp. at 121-22 (docket no. 148); 

[TEXT]
<line: 58> j. 
<line: 59> Eko Brands’ request for a permanent injunction is GRANTED in part and 
<line: 60> DENIED in part; and 

[ABANDON]
<line: 62> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 40 

[TEXT]
<line: 2> 1
<line: 3> 2
<line: 4> 3
<line: 5> 4
<line: 6> 5
<line: 7> 6
<line: 8> 7
<line: 9> 8
<line: 10> 9
<line: 11> 10
<line: 12> 11
<line: 13> 12
<line: 14> 13
<line: 15> 14
<line: 16> 15
<line: 17> 16
<line: 18> 17
<line: 19> 18
<line: 20> 19
<line: 21> 20
<line: 22> 21
<line: 23> 22
<line: 24> 23
<line: 25> FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW - 41 
<line: 26> k. 
<line: 27> Eko Brands’ request to cancel the federal registrations for ECO FILL, 
<line: 28> ECO CARAFE, and ECO FILTER is DENIED. 
<line: 29> 71. 
<line: 30> Defendants’ motion for judgment, docket no. 125, is GRANTED in part 
<line: 31> and DENIED in part as set forth in these Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law. 
<line: 32> 72. 
<line: 33> The Clerk is DIRECTED to enter judgment consistent with these Findings 
<line: 34> of Fact and Conclusions of Law and to send a copy of the Judgment and these Findings 
<line: 35> of Fact and Conclusions of Law to all counsel of record.  Eko Brands may tax costs in the 
<line: 36> manner set forth in Local Civil Rule 54(d), and any motion for attorney’s fees shall be 
<line: 37> filed by the deadline specified in Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 54(d)(2)(B). 
<line: 38> IT IS SO ORDERED. 
<line: 39> Dated this 30th day of January, 2020. 
<line: 40> A 
<line: 41> Thomas S. Zilly 
<line: 42> United States District Judge 

[TEXT]

[ABANDON]
